title: Can Google read my mails? - Quora

response.answer_text: The revised version more clearly describes how Google software scans the user's email, both when the message is stored on Google's server and when it's in transit. Last month, a US judge decided not to put together a single class action lawsuit in which Google sued for infringing hundreds of millions of email users' privacy rights. Users of Google's Gmail mail service have violated federal and state privacy and eavesdropping laws by scanning their messages so that they can create secret profiles and target ads. And accusing the company. Google claims that users implicitly agree to the activity and acknowledge it as part of the email delivery process. Does Gmail read my email? Many people are concerned about their online privacy. It is good to worry about who can access your information, especially what is included in your personal email. If you're a Gmail user, you may have noticed hyper-specific ads, such as ads for products and services related to send and receive email that appear when you use the service. Read your email, Google employees do not personally read your email, but are scanned to deliver more relevant ads and search results. It is possible to turn off these ads, but Gmail will scan the content of your email as a security measure. We discuss the pros and cons of this, how to opt out, and what if you don't like the idea of ​​Gmail monitoring.

Yes. The terms and conditions you accepted when you signed up for gmail include: We also collect the content you create, upload, or receive from others when using our services. This includes things like email you write and receive, photos and videos you save, docs and spreadsheets you create, and comments you make on YouTube videos. So, yes, the Google algorithm does look at your email content, and shows you ads based on that content. It also checks the content for spam, checks it to auto add stuff like diary entries, delivery information and flight info and a whole load of other stuff. Email is moderately expensive to provide, especially at that kind of scale. To pay for all this, Google shows ads. By scanning the content to show more relevant ads, the advertisers get better response rates, and so are willing to pay more for the ads. This does not mean the advertisers have your info. you are just lumped in with a group of people flagged as ‘male, 35–55, likes cars’ or whatever. It does not always get this right. You can check who Google thinks you are in the personal advertising data area, and even delete stuff that is wrong, if it’s showing you annoying ads. You can get email that does not do this, but you are going to have to pay for it.

Every piece of mail that GMail processes gets scanned to see if it’s spam. There are those who claim that this is Google reading your mail. I can understand that position, but anyone who’s seen what an unfiltered email feed looks like in 2018 knows that email that isn’t filtered is email that can’t be used. As far as humans reading your email goes, there are few circumstances where this will happen. If you’re a person of interest in a criminal investigation and Google’s been ordered to turn your email over by a court, that can happen.[1] If there’s a bug in GMail, and it can’t be fixed without someone looking at email, that can happen too. In general, though, nobody at Google wants to read your email. I’d lose my job in a hot second if I even tried, and rightly so. Footnotes[1] Way of a Warrant

Assuming you’re asking if Google employees are reading your email, then no. Hopefully not. Few of them would be able to, and the one person I’m aware of who was caught abusing the privilege was fired. If, however, you’re asking if Google’s computers data-mine your email corpus for the purposes of advertising and improving its services, then of course it does—just like every other free service. Edit: For completeness, don’t forget that if you have any 3rd-party browser extensions or any of the new Gmail extensions, all bets are off. If you install one, make sure you trust the extension maker!

Are people at Google reading my Gmail? I spent the greater part of my working life in telecommunications. That started with Morse Code back in the 1950s the progressed to teleprinters before moving on to computers. Every telegram (a kind of prehistoric email) that came through my hands had to be read word by word, letter by letter. With rare exceptions, they were forgotten as soon as I moved on to the next message. The words went in through my eyes, scrambled around in my brain, and re-emerged from my fingertips without taking root. To professionals, other people’s private messages are rarely interesting. Even if it were possible for Google’s employees to read your emails, why on earth would they want to? Is your life so uniquely entertaining as all that? Of course, if you were involved in criminal or terrorist activities, you’d have bigger problems than Google. Then you’d have to worry about the NSA, or GHQ, or whichever spy agency is operating on your part of the Internet.

Certainly not! Gmail has more than 1 billion (!) active users per month. In another thread here from 2014 someone mentions a statistic of 294 billion sent emails per day over Gmail. The people at Google spend their time and energy developing new, exciting, and very helpful technology procucts. Not (!) reading your email. So you can be relaxed, okay? I myself use Gmail on a daily basis for a long long time now. And as I have been working for them myself, I know that we are safe. All the best, Sebastian

To be absolutely clear: no one at Google reads your Gmail, except in very specific cases where you ask us to and give consent, or where we need to for security purposes, such as investigating a bug or abuse.[1] Always read the company, service, and software privacy policy. Footnotes[1] Google clarifies Gmail inbox privacy policy after user backlash

Of course. Google as a company does read all your emails, but not Google as a human being. Advanced ML algorithms parse through emails to categorise them into priority, social, promotions etc. However, I'm pretty sure individuals/engineers in Google cannot read any of these mails - the storage of these mails would be encrypted as well.

Of course they can. So can any email provider, and so can any mail relay your mail goes through on its way to its destination. If this bothers you, your only recourse (other than not using email) is to encrypt anything sensitive before you send it and make arrangements for the receiver to be able to decrypt it. (Note that connections to Gmail are now encrypted, but that’s a different question).

Yes, if you want to avoid that you should use a mail service which uses encryption by default instead like Protonmail. Each mail that is stored in your mailbox is stored unencrypted, otherwise it would not be possible to read the mail with IMAP or on the webmail

“Can Google read my emails?” If you ask them to, yes. Otherwise the answer is they don’t read your email. Nor do they scan it to target ads. They do scan it to find viruses and spam, which is why Gmail is awesome.
no. google is matching words in your searches to products in databases, and presenting ads based on those matches.
